Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the parent needs to provide it
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: Every morning, I wake before dawn, quietly moving through the house so as not to disturb my sleeping children. As a parent, I feel the weight of responsibility pressing on me—rent is due soon, groceries are running low, and my job has asked me to come in early for extra shifts. The money is needed, desperately, to keep our family afloat. Yet, as a Hindu, I have always set aside this sacred time to light the lamp and offer prayers at our home altar. My mother taught me that these rituals bring peace and blessings to the household, and I want to pass that on to my children. Today, my phone buzzes with a message from my boss: “Can you come in right now? We need you.” I glance at the clock. If I leave immediately, I’ll make it on time, but I’ll have to skip my morning prayers. My heart pounds as I stand in the hallway, torn between the urgent need to provide for my family and the deep pull of my faith, both demanding my presence at the same moment.
